Recognizing that a purely secular and relativistic utilitarianism could as easily produce terrible outcomes as good ones, Joseph Fletcher attempted to fix the problem by suggesting love as the defining characteristic of "the greater good". Unfortunately this didn't fix the problem, as any means, however terrible, could still potentially be justified in the pursuit of a "loving" goal.

There has never been a political system, whether secular or not, whether democratic or not, that is immune from abuse, immune from developing within itself systemic injustice. Nor is it true to say that only theists can live morally upright lives. There are certainly many non-theists who are deeply committed to the well-being of humanity, to environmental responsibility, and who live exemplary lives of service and compassion, just as there are many self-described theists who do not. But it is true that, once a society's values, as embodied in its legislation, have become essentially disconnected from any reference to absolute moral authority (such as God), there follows a cultural drift towards moral relativism and the kind of utilitarian ethics exemplified in the writings of the philosopher Peter Singer.
 
Commendable as the stated goals of utilitarianism may be, in a morally relativistic secular society governed according to utilitarian principles the definition of "the greater good" is in effect determined by those who have the greatest influence. This necessarily ends up devolving essentially into the rule of the strong over the weak, however much the society might wish either to avoid this outcome or try to make it appear otherwise. In a secular capitalist society, the "greater good" is inevitably measured in economic terms, automatically casting needy individuals as "liabilities", as having net negative value to society. This ultimately also undermines the sort of democracy that is traditional in the West, as it represents the rejection of a foundational principle: the inherent dignity and equality of all people.

While it's a sufficient example to poke at act utilitarianism, it actually pokes far deeper than the patching to rule utilitariansim can cover. To see how, all you have to do is imagine the same scenario in a desert-island type setting. There's a robot doctor present, capable of performing the organ transplant. Imagine there are only 3 people - 2 patients who need vital organs and 1 who could give them to both. Do the 2 ethically order the robot doctor to harvest organs?

Rule-utilitarianisms' appeal doesn't seem to me to apply (much) here. Because there's no greater society, and hence no precedent is set at large. Moreover, only 2 humans remain afterwards. So there's no further possibility of killing some to save more. Suppose they are both the same sex so no future society will emerge.

While a rather elaborate example, it seems to me that this points to a deeper issue with act utilitarianism that rule utilitarianisms' rationale doesn't apply to. For me, what comes up is issues around self-sovereignty, which are deeply violated when a society or individual deems you should die for a greater good. It just seems wrong to violate someone's self-sovereignty to this degree.

I guess rule utilitarianism could attempt to make a play on those grounds - self-sovereignty is a rule that contributes in an important way to well-being. Violating it does real damage to the ability to believe it will hold in the future (even in the society of 2), and hence does real harm to well-being.

I don't think I'm being a moral realist here. I don't have the view that others should necessarily share this view about self-sovereignty, bc I don't think there's anything sufficiently objective about it. It's more of a moral subjective stance. Operationally, I value my self-sovereignty so much that it's hard to make it OK for me to violate someone else's in a deep way like this. It's quite possible that other people in other societies don't value self-sovereignty to this degree. So it would be OK for them.

Utilitarianism is close to correct but not quite. We should do things to achieve the best outcomes because...that will lead to the best outcome. But the thought experiments proposed don't consider the whole outcome, only selected parts of it. If we were to live in a society where doctors could kill us to save many other lives, while more people might survive, it might result in perpetual fear throughout society, and that fear might lower total happiness. It might also result in a decreased incentive to find alternative methods to sustain human life, and such a finding would result in even more happiness (I don't like using happiness, let's replace it with the fulfillment of values). If you can just kill random lonely people when you need to save a bunch of other people, then there would be less motivation to find a solution that will save those people without relying on the death of another.

Another problem with utilitarianism is that it contains a principle that holds it back from fulfilling its stated goal "the greatest happiness for the greatest amount of people" or using my preferred language "the maximization of the fulfillment of values." This principle is the one that we shouldn't prioritize ourselves over others, we are no different. But if we are seeking the maximization of the fulfillment of values, then the best person who is the most equipped to fulfill your values IS YOU. When we work to fulfill our own values, we are increasing the total happiness in the world. If your life is going well, then others will have less reason to devote resources like time and energy on you and they can either allocate that towards other people or themselves.

AU and RU are anachronistic when applied to Bentham and Mill. Consequentialism has also been argued as anachronistic. It's a 20th century term being applied to 19th century moral theory. This video only examines Bentham's account of utilitarianism and does not even touch on Mill's continuation and restructuring of it. In fact, many of the same criticisms people have of Mill, Mill had of Bentham. Mill's theory is very complex including internal and external sanctions, moral character as a construct of eduction and proper upbringing, and a discussion of virtue (Aristotle), as well as Will and Desire.

This video is of someone who might have read Bentham, and maybe chapters 1 and 2 of Mill's "Utilitarianism", but not chapters 3 through 5. If you had read them and understood them, then you would see that Mill's Utilitarian theory is far more comprehensive then just weighing the pleasures and pains of a situation and acting upon that. That's Bentham and easily disputed. Mill's problems are far more subtle and rooted in his logical system and metaphysics.

Also, you forgot to mention one of the most interestins aspects of Utilitarianism: it accounts for everyone including animals. Thus, giving an argument for vegetarianism (Peter Singer), women's rights (Mill's "The Subjection of Women"), and against racism. Also, Mill explicitly argues against tyranny of the majority in "On Liberty" (chapter 2). My personal critique of utilitarianism: to judge the morality of actions or to institute norms based solely on their consequences is a dangerous thing to do, not because you might fall on some of these thought experiments, but because you attribute an ethic to an external purpose. Utilitarianism guides ethics in order to attain a greater good, pleasure or utility, much like a recipe book. If you want a happy society, follow these instructions; if you want to bake a cake, do as listed in the recipe book. However, it begs the question: why are these objectives desired, or even there, in the first place? These objectives are certainly outside the field of reason itself to be justified solely by it. Wanting to bake a cake is as much a subjective purpose or want as is wanting a more utilitarian society. This is the essence of the kantian morality: kant justified his ethic not in an external purpose or objective, subjective in nature, but justified in reason itself. This is namely the categorical imperative, that which is good, necessary and universal, contrary to the hypothetical imperative, a recipe for a desired subjective want.

I think my biggest problem with utilitarianism is the assumption of authority on behalf of the actor. In each of these given examples in the video, the authority to enact these so-called 'utilitarian' measures is assumed by the actor, making him/her the only (pro)active agent and reducing all other participants into reactive agents/victims. It also seems to reduce consequences and options to unrealistic binaries, forcing the active participant down a specific route as the scenario is framed in such a way as to make only one route possible and moral. What I like about Kantian ethics is the absolutist vision (say, in regards to a refusal to take life) rests on the pretext of any encounter that the subject has no real right or authority to make such a weighty decision as to take life. It also recognizes that consequence as a result of a utilitarian action is really unknowable. The problem with utilitarianism is, in short, the butterfly effect; determining your ethics by the consequences of your actions forces you to grapple with the fact that consequences are often unpredictable and inconsistent. If Batman kills the Joker, he leaves something of a power vacuum in Gotham (unless we're talking about Silver Age Joker), which could give rise to an even worse evil. Or Harley Quinn could nuke the city in revenge or something. If the man shoots the native, the soldiers could just throw all the prisoners in solitary confinement cells until they starve, killing them even more painfully. Funnily enough, I would argue that Batman is following Rule Utilitarianism by not killing the Joker.

One of the main reasons he tends to give for not killing the Joker (or other villains he faces) is that "he's not a judge". He sees himself as equivalent to a SWAT officer - someone who's job is to bring the suspects into custody so they can be tried in a court of law. His unspoken rationale would be that "If he kills someone, then he's acting as judge, jury and executioner. And if HE'S allowed to do that, what's stopping the rest of the public from doing it?"

Sure, this argument is very flawed (if you want to act within the law, then why are you breaking into buildings and threatening people instead of sending Police tip-offs?), but his situation is extreme: the Gotham police department is powerless to stop these super-criminals. So when the people who are supposed to protect us fail in their job, what are we supposed to do?

That's why he's such an imposing yet admirable hero: he's straddling the line of citizen activism without crossing over into full on vigilantism that could see the rule of law go up in (possibly quite literal) flames. And in so doing, he's modeling the essence of Rule Utilitarianism's future-seeing ethics: if he keeps throwing enough of them in prison and keeps them off the streets long enough, then maybe the police will have time to recover and strengthen enough to take the streets back; maybe good people will eventually get elected to positions of power instead of being bribed or intimidated into submission because nobody will be left to do said bribing or intimidating; maybe his city will stop being cowed and beaten down long enough to fight back LEGALLY and win the streets of Gotham.

Sadly, the upper crust of Gotham tend to all be snooty assholes who don't care about the rest of Gotham since it doesn't affect them, and that's one of Batman's greatest problems: since the super-villains take care to avoid affecting the rich too much until they're ready to take the city whole-cloth, Batman can't show those people the truth like he can the poor and downtrodden. And Bruce can't do too much too quickly without making himself a target and exposing Batman. So the rich only see Batman as a criminal who's not as bad as Joker or Two-Face. And since they're largely paid by said upper-crust (and since he's interfering with their work and breaking established laws to do it), the Police as a whole see him as a criminal, as well, taking the stance that "If he really wants to help, he'd take off the mask and put on a badge like we did; sooner or later, he's going to slip up and kill someone this way".

So to sum up: Batman won't kill the Joker because he doesn't want others to then follow in his footsteps and start killing all the criminals in Gotham, which would leave the rule of law burning along with the city. He's trying to find the best outcome for the long-term, when the short-term good would be to kill Joker and Two-Face and all the rest. And that's Rule Utilitarianism at its core. HE isn't the one at fault for the Joker getting out and killing again: it's the law-makers for not changing the laws to have Joker thrown in a real prison when Batman brings them in; it's those in charge of Arkum Asylum for not spending the money to beef up security to ensure their charges don't escape (or better yet, rebuild the place from scratch); and it's those in powers' fault for letting the city continue to rot so that Joker continues to have desperate underlings who want the power and money he promises in exchange for helping him bust out yet again.
